	</item>
	<item>
		<title>What Makes You a Good Quality Analyst?</title>
		<link>http://dreamhtml.com/techies-new/good-quality-analyst/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 11 Feb 2015 07:54:35 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[webmaster]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://techiesindiainc.com/?p=2155</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In software industry its really difficult to validate and verify a product. First question is are we building right product ? if yes, then Next question is are we building the product right? So here comes the role of a software tester, whose sole responsibility is to analyze the client's requirement, refine them as much as he can, Raising questions how and why?

<a href="http://techiesindiainc.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Abhishek-QA1.jpg"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2161" src="http://techiesindiainc.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Abhishek-QA1.jpg" alt="Abhishek-Q&amp;A" width="594" height="774" /></a>

A software tester should have deep knowledge about the product being developed irrespective of the fact whether the product is in initial analysis phase or final phase of testing. Sofware Tester must be a good team player, should possess good analytic skills,should have understanding of potential market,and should be able to get into end user's shoes to understand how useful the product is to the end user.

Hence the most important skills which a good software tester must possess would be:
<ul>
	<li><strong>Always be skeptical:</strong></li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Never believe that the complete software or a module given to you for testing is bug free.A software can never be bug free no matter how sophisticated approach has been taken to write the code.Also doesn't matters what designation the programmers has. Just use your experience and your knowledge to find out the possible loopholes in the system.</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Never Compromise on Quality</strong></li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Do not compromise quality after a certain testing stage.There should never be a limit to testing unless you achieve a quality product.Compromising quality at any stage can lead to lower overall quality of the final product and can have serious implications in long term.</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Vouch for end user satisfaction:</strong></li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Always think about making end users happy. After all we are developing a software to make end user's life easier.And a piece of software that can't meet the end user's satisfaction can not stay in the marker for longer. In current era of cutting edge competition ultimately another software which can ensure and maintain a level of end user satisfaction will bring your software down.</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Think from Users Perspective</strong></li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Remember we produce software for users. Think from a user perspective try to identify as much as you can what user actually want from that software. A user may or may not be that technical.If you do not think with user perspective you will certainly miss many loopholes or you can say "Bugs".users location,age and even their qualification may matter while using software. A software product can be successful only if it provides user an ease of use and finally can make them happy.</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Be Open to Suggestions</strong></li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Be open listen to everyone around you even if you are in authority to that project and having the depth knowledge of the project.Always welcome suggestions as you always have some possibilities of further improvements, gettingan insight from fellow testers is always a good idea.Everyone's suggestions and valuable feedback will ultimately contribute in delivering a bug free software to end users and stake holders of the project.</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Do Market Research</strong></li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Never think your duty is to validate the final software product on the basis of client's requirement be proactive research market, see how other similar product in market having the same functionality are working.Research what makes other products more interactive then yours.At the end of the day the research you did will help you understand the product and its potential market.</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Stop the blame Game</strong></li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">In case of a bug encountered by client or end users you will always we attacked with questions from management or even developers that why the bug was not unleashed during the process of testing. This is even common where a testers responsibilities are not well defined. Stay calm and put your focus on getting it resolved rather than finding someone to blame.As a human everyone makes a mistake, so avoid blaming others.Work as a team to build team spirit.</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Be diplomatic</strong></li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Sometimes while you are in-charge of the project you will have to hide certain things from client and even from developers. Sometimes you will have to take decision of a release even if you know there are certain bugs in the product,.But always keep a secret bucket with yourself to keep those bugs with yourself and get them resolved as soon as possible. And this is not wrong at any level as developers and testers have the same goal that is overall quality and success of the product they are working upon.</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Learn to negotiate</strong></li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Tester need to negotiate at every level of software development life cycle.specially negotiation with developers is most important.Developers will do everything to prove that their code is perfect and bug logged by a tester is not valid.It requires great skills to convince developers about the defect and get it resolved.Some testers may thinkthat its not their task but explaining the developers the true impact of a flaw is really helpful for developers to understand overall scenario and implications.</p>

<ul>
	<li><strong>Finally, Be a Good Observer</strong></li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Minutely observe the things happening around you. keep a track of minor and major things taking place in the project. Observe the way coding is being done.Get involved with development team, Spend sometimes with them, try to understand problems they are facing. If they are having trouble understanding the client's requirement explain them. Most importantly respect the development team,They are the only reason you are here.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Cheers !
Happy Testing</p>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>What Should Be Your Approach As An Intern?</title>
		<link>http://dreamhtml.com/techies-new/your-approach-as-an-intern/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 18 Feb 2015 06:13:20 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[webmaster]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://techiesindiainc.com/?p=2168</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[I had started my career as an Intern PHP Developer at Techies India Inc. Like anyone, I was quite excited yet a little nervous considering what would be the new environment, what sort of people will I get the chance to meet, what will be the challenges and What should be my strategies to deal with the same. Keeping all these hows and whens I entered in to my professional battle.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2169" src="http://techiesindiainc.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/ritu.jpg" alt="ritu" width="594" height="774" />

I obviously had a lot to learn as everything around was new to me, whether its about my approach to a new organization or learning about new tricks &amp; technologies about web development.

I am a person who likes to have a plan for anything which i opt for and so do anyone else should have. So here i am going to share few things i observed during my tenure which helped me out to make my journey smooth and successful.
<h3>Lets start with the approach to appear as an asset for the organisation:-</h3>
<ul>
	<li><b>You might be overwhelmed by all the new work culture</b> : Don't freak out about it. There is a theory that you can only retain some part of the information that's thrown at you during your first day on a job if the environment is a fast-paced one. This is normal. Eventually youll get use to it.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><b> Listen each and everything carefully and sincerely :</b>The first week is about assembling a framework of understanding about company culture.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><b>Ask more Questions</b> :The important thing is that dont be shy about asking questions. Frankly, it's unnerving when a new employee doesn't ask questions, because this signifies that either you're too shy or not paying enough attention to realize the things. However, to the extent that you're able to save up your questions and ask them in bunches. This way, you're interrupting less and getting the information you need.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><b>Consider Expectations of your Manager</b> : Try to find out what are the hopes of your manager at the start.Which are the main and important projects you should be focus immediately? What would be the successful outcomes for those?</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><b>Mental Presence</b> : Pay attention to the culture.Observe how others act and you'll absorb a ton of information about cultural expectations which obviously depends on your presence of mind. Are people compulsively on time for meetings? What hours do most people work? what is their communication medium? Be yourself and try to fit into the basic parameters.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><b>Seek Help</b> : Don't turn down colleagues if they are willing to help. Even if you feel that you don't need one, accept it as an assistance. In a nutshell, you'll begin forming bonds and it will be helpful for you to gain information. After all, you don't know what you might not know.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><b>Maintain Standards</b> : Being a developer your first consideration should always about standardizing your codes.</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li><b>Review Information</b> : Review the gathered informative material and you are good to go. I'm convinced no one does this, and I'm also convinced they should.</li>
</ul>
So these were the tips towards the general behavior which will make your organisation consider you as an asset but dont forget your basic agenda like as the internship you are being hired for? As i was being hired for PHP Development, I am going to share things which helped me out to take my development career to a new level. I hope this is gonna help you the same way.
<h3>Learn To Set Up Your Own PHP Environment</h3>
As a new joinee we are not sure about what will be the output after our coding process. Sometimes our system may hang or be damaged with our wrong process which can create a lot of trouble.So, the solution to the problem is to install the virtualization software. You can install the virtualization software and run a Linux virtual machine.You can literally experiment as much as you want without fear of messing anything up.Experimenting with your own setups will also allow you to get familiar with the different servers.
<h3>Exercise Best Practices Early</h3>
While writing your code, comment heavily using docblocks and beautify it via indentation. Use documentation tools to extract docblocks and edit them accordingly.
<h3>Choose a Good IDE</h3>
Choose a good IDE considering the disk space. PHPStorm can be a good choice or if you can't afford it or have no open source projects with which to ask for a free license, Netbeans is a free alternative. Both are multi-platform.
<h3>Try Out Different Frameworks, Choose One</h3>
For a long period of time, PHP has huge number of frameworks.When you will use these frameworks.You will learn about a new approach to a common problem every time. you'll learn about the mindset of others You'll see new usages and approaches, and a very good exercise is re-building one of your sample projects in as many frameworks as you can find.This will help you in your work efficiency along with speed of the developing and its performance.
<h3>Read Useful Material</h3>
Tips and hints on anywhere are the powerful feature. So dont underestimate it.These links and hints will not take much time but will help you alot. So must be read the tutorials on the website and answers on Stack Overflow,visit the SitePoint Forums, subscribe to newsletters, follow good sources on Google+.Dont follow the basic PHP tutorial.These are mostly outdated.So focus on up-to-date code to all over the web.
<h3>Engage Yourself In Something Fruitful</h3>
Keep working, keep yourself interested and engaged. Make a simple address book app. Then rebuild it in another framework. Then rebuild it with another database MongoDB, for example. Keep busy!

So at last i will end up with these beautiful words by Robert kiyosaki<b> </b><i>Face your Fears and Doubts, and new Worlds will open to you.</i><b></b>
<h3>Thanks</h3>
&nbsp;

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Add More Muscle to your CSS with Sass</title>
		<link>http://dreamhtml.com/techies-new/add-muscle-css-sass/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Feb 2015 06:31:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[webmaster]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://techiesindiainc.com/?p=2178</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[One of our recent projects needed a substantial amount of coding. During the process of development, however, we noted that we had to re-use bits of codes that not only took time, but also were prone to errors. As a result, unnecessary time was spent on re-doing the same block of codes at different places and needed as many rounds of checking as its number of iterations. How we so much wished for a tool that will help us so away with these redundancies and still be effective with our programming!<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2184" src="http://techiesindiainc.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/surinder-post.png" alt="surinder-post" width="594" height="774" />
<p align="JUSTIFY">A little bit of digging online helped us discover <b>Sass</b>. And we were completely blown away by the way it extended the functionality and usage of CSS without over-complicating things. To take an example at a very high level, the below in green are two blocks of codes that have been used at multiple places.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">p { </span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">margin : 5px;</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">padding: 8px;</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">font-size: 110%;</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">color: green</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">text-align: justify;</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">}</span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">footer { </span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">margin : 5px;</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">padding: 8px;</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">font-size: 110%;</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">color: green</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">text-align: justify;</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY">}</p>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Now imagine if we can in any way define these parameters in green at one place and just use its reference name. The above example will then fit in just two lines instead of 10 lines of code. If the green code was used in 5 places throughout the program, it wouldve resulted in just 5 lines of code, instead of a huge 25 lines of code. This is precisely what Sass allowed us to do. The new code would look something like this </p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">@mixin fontprop</span></span> <span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">{ </span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">margin : 5px;</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">padding: 8px;</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">font-size: 110%;</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">color: green</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">text-align: justify;</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">}</span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">p {@include </span></span></span><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;"><b>fontprop</b></span></span></span><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">}</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">footer {@include </span></span></span><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;"><b>fontprop</b></span></span></span><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">}</span></span></span></p>

<h3 align="JUSTIFY">What happens behind the scene?</h3>
<p align="JUSTIFY">When Sass is processed, it takes the parameters defined in <span style="color: #2f5496;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">fontprop </span></span></span>after the <span style="color: #2f5496;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">mixin</span></span></span> directive and outputs normal CSS with the variable values placed in the CSS. This results in easy to maintain shorter code, lesser processing time, lesser checking and testing and better consistency throughout the program.</p>
<p align="JUSTIFY">With our interest piqued, we applied Sass with amazing results on other parts of the CSS program with the same results as above. Having gained a fair bit of experience on this immensely nifty CSS extension, we share our thoughts with you on this blog. Here are some basics on Sass.</p>

<h3 align="JUSTIFY">What is Sass?</h3>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Short for <span style="text-decoration: underline;">S</span>yntactically <span style="text-decoration: underline;">A</span>wesome <span style="text-decoration: underline;">S</span>tyle<span style="text-decoration: underline;">s</span>heets, Sass is a CSS extension language that is gaining prominence due to its stability, high performance and functionality it provides to CSS stylesheets. It is completely compatible with all versions of CSS so that any CSS library can be used with Sass without any issues. It provides OOP functionalities previously missing with default CSS.</p>

<h3 align="JUSTIFY">How does it add more value to CSS?</h3>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Sass provides many functionalities not available with CSS script. As a result the usage and effectiveness of CSS is tremendously enhanced. Here are some ways in which Sass extends the prowess of CSS </p>

<ol>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><b>Variables</b>  With variables, certain properties, parameters or block of features can be reused many times without the need for defining or specifying it again and again. So if you assign a variable to a specific color in order to avoid reusing the same color code, you can do it as</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">$green: #3bbf00</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY">Now you can use the <span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">$green </span></span></span>variable as below</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">p { </span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">margin : 5px;</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">padding: 8px;</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">color: </span></span></span><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;"><b>$green</b></span></span></span><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">; }</span></span></span></p>

<ol start="2">
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><b>Mixins</b>  The <span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">fontprop</span></span></span> example shown in first part of this blog is a noteworthy example of using mixins and achieving functionality not possible within default CSS scripts.</p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><b>Nesting</b>  Unlike HTML, CSS doesnt provide for visual hierarchy or nested appearance of code. With Sass, this can be accomplished easily. This feature provides a well-organized CSS code and facilitates better readability.</p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><b>Selector inheritance</b>  By using @extend, Sass overcomes CSS3 limitations on inheritance and helps share properties of one selector to another. So if we want to justify-align the paragraph at a margin of 5 points, zoom in the font by 110% and give it green color, then we can collect these in one block of reusable code. Our code would look like this</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">.usethis {margin : 5px;</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">font-size: 110%;</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">color: green</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">text-align: justify;}</span></span></span></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Suppose later on we want to use these parameters in addition to some more specific parameter, we can inherit the properties using <span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">@extend </span></span></span>directive as shown below</p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">.spinoff {</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">@extend .usethis;</span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY"><span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">border-color: blue;} </span></span></span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;" align="JUSTIFY">Now wherever <span style="color: #007600;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;">.spinoff </span></span></span>is used, it will justify-align the paragraph at a margin of 5 points, zoom in the font by 110% and give it green color AND provide a blue color border.</p>

<ol start="5">
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><b>Abides by the DRY principle</b>  The DRY principle states <span style="color: #222222;"><span style="font-family: Georgia, serif;"><i>Every piece of knowledge must have a single, unambiguous, authoritative representation within a system.</i></span></span> Sass helps achieve this rule, as we have succinctly depicted in our actual example above.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<h3 align="JUSTIFY">Our Takeaways</h3>
<p align="JUSTIFY">CSS itself is a good way to apply dynamic styling, but there are certain aspects yet not a part of the language, such as mixins, variables, or inheritance. These can be easily controlled and used by using Sass, our favorite CSS preprocessor tool currently!</p>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>How Yii helps preventing Cross Site Scripting (XSS) attack?</title>
		<link>http://dreamhtml.com/techies-new/yii-helps-preventing-cross-site-scripting-xss-attack/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 04 Mar 2015 10:34:58 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[webmaster]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://techiesindiainc.com/?p=2187</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[As part of the core TII development team, my responsibility is to work towards better Web 2.0 applications. This helps my team and me to provide future-ready IT solutions to our clients. A lot of my work revolves round YII, the high performance PHP framework that provides the right kind of flexibility for us to develop websites and applications of any scale or complexity.
<p align="JUSTIFY">YII not only follows OOP principles, but also conforms to advanced PHP features such as SPL classes and interfaces and late static binding. One key element that helps me tremendously is YIIs ability to thwart Cross Site Scripting (XSS) attack. This is made possible with HtmlPurifier helper class, and the associated component, CHtmlPurifier.</p>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Today I will share some thoughts on this XSS attack and how I have used YIIs powerful features to prevent this malicious attack for my development projects.</p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2188" src="http://techiesindiainc.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/bal.png" alt="bal" width="594" height="774" /></p>

<h3 align="JUSTIFY">How the attack is carried out?</h3>
<p align="JUSTIFY">A website that doesnt have filtering capability for user input or escape output, is prone to third party scripts to be attached to the input. It can be any script that can be executed on the client side (majorly using JavaScript). This malicious script then gathers data illegitimately from a user when he/she views the web page in a browser.</p>
<p align="JUSTIFY">There are two types of XSS injections  non-persistent and persistent</p>

<ol>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Non-persistent  This is a common XSS found in most insecure web applications that works only once and only for one user. The data passed by the user is not stored externally. As compared to persistent code, the degree of threat is lower.</p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Persistent  This is a more serious XSS threat where data passed by user is stored in an external database and is available for access to other website users (usually hackers)</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p align="JUSTIFY">I will take up an example of non-persistent XSS injection and how YII actually helps in this case.</p>

<h3 align="JUSTIFY">XSS attack and YII resolution</h3>
<p align="JUSTIFY">o when the PHP code is</p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><em><span style="color: #3b3838;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">public function checkname()</span></span></span></em></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><em><span style="color: #3b3838;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">{</span></span></span></em></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><em><span style="color: #3b3838;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">echo This is test for .$_GET[userid].!;</span></span></span></em></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><em><span style="color: #3b3838;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">}</span></span></span></em></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY">..the URL shows <em><span style="color: #3b3838;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">/xss/text?userid=ABC</span></span></span></em>. However will malicious code attached the URL will look like</p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><em><span style="color: #3b3838;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">/xss/test?userid=&lt;script&gt;alert(HACKED);&lt;/script&gt;</span></span></span></em></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY">..and the result will be an alert dialog box with the words HACKED</p>

<h3 align="JUSTIFY">How YII helps?</h3>
<p align="JUSTIFY">At a very high level, the CHtmlPurifier that encapsulates the HtmlPurifier class, removes all malicious code with a rigorous audit against a secure whitelist and ensures that the code is W3C standards compliant.</p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><em><span style="color: #3b3838;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">public function checkname()</span></span></span></em></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><em><span style="color: #3b3838;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">{</span></span></span></em></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><em><span style="color: #3b3838;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">echo This is test for </span></span></span><span style="color: #ff0000;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">.CHtml::encode(</span></span></span><span style="color: #3b3838;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">.$_GET[userid]</span></span></span><span style="color: #ff0000;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">)</span></span></span><span style="color: #3b3838;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">.!;</span></span></span></em></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><em><span style="color: #3b3838;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">}</span></span></span></em></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"> the result will now show <span style="font-size: medium;">This is test for &lt;script&gt;alert(XSS);&lt;/script&gt;!</span></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY">This way you can escape dynamic data and prevent XSS code injection.</p>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Lets now go one step ahead and look at how to pass HTML code and show a codes implementation rather than the code itself. Using CHtml::encode will read the HTML code literally. What we will need is the superior performance of YII. This framework provides the built-in HtmlPurifier helper class that allows passing of HTML code present within the beginWidget/endWidget tag</p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><em><span style="color: #3b3838;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">public function checkname()</span></span></span></em></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><em><span style="color: #3b3838;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">{</span></span></span></em></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><em><span style="color: #3b3838;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">$this-&gt;beginWidget(CHtmlPurifier); echo $_GET(html);</span></span></span></em></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><em><span style="color: #3b3838;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">$this-&gt;endWidget();</span></span></span></em></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><em><span style="color: #3b3838;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">}</span></span></span></em></p>
Now you can implement the html action using the URL :

<em><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">/xss/html?html= This is, &lt;em&gt;username&lt;/em&gt;!&lt;script&gt;alert(XSS)&lt;/script&gt;</span></span></em>

and the output on the page will be:

This is, <i>username</i>!
<p align="JUSTIFY">As you can see the emphasis tag now renders correctly on the screen.</p>

<h3 align="JUSTIFY">Constructing the HtmlPurifier</h3>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Setting up and configuring the HtmlPurifier is important to enhance the functionality and usability across the code.</p>

<ol>
	<li>Usage as a class</li>
</ol>
&nbsp;
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><em><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">$p = new CHtmlPurifier();</span></span></span></em></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><em><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">$p-&gt;options = array('URI.AllowedSchemes'=&gt;array(</span></span></span></em></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><em><span style="color: #000000;"> <span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">'http' =&gt; true,</span></span></span></em></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><em><span style="color: #000000;"> <span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">'https' =&gt; true,</span></span></span></em></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><em><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">));</span></span></span></em></p>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><em><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">$text = $p-&gt;purify($text);</span></span></span></em></p>
&nbsp;
<ol start="2">
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Usage as validation rule</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p style="padding-left: 30px;"><em><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New';"><span style="font-size: small;">array('text','filter','filter'=&gt;array($obj=new CHtmlPurifier(),'purify')),</span></span></span></em></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Another important point to note is that HtmlPurifier is a big package and can gobble up valuable system resources. A work around can be to</p>

<ol>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Caching the purification result, or</p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Purifying the user input before it is saved to the database.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<h3 align="JUSTIFY">To wrap up</h3>
<p align="JUSTIFY">My experience with YII has been highly satisfactory. It has proven itself as a stable PHP framework that helps us to employ it in any web application project of any scale, size or complexity. Its robust performance even in face of malicious XSS injection attacks helps to deliver stable IT solutions to your clients, without worrying about external hacks or attacks. This is possible due to the in-built HtmlPurifier, the standards-compliant HTML filer library written in PHP.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Benefits of Custom Post Type or Taxonomy in WordPress</title>
		<link>http://dreamhtml.com/techies-new/custom-post-type-taxonomy-wordpress/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 11 Mar 2015 09:32:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[webmaster]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://techiesindiainc.com/?p=2194</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[With most of my TIIs projects based on WordPress, I had to eventually come across Custom post type or taxonomy sooner or later. Having worked with them on four projects, I guess the time has come to share with you the benefits of utilizing custom post type and taxonomies and where it shows its true potential. This will help you decide on using these powerful ways to create customized WordPress applications

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2195" src="http://techiesindiainc.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/vikas-sansoa.jpg" alt="vikas-sansoa" width="574" height="794" />

<strong>What are custom post types and taxonomies?</strong>

With the current position as one of the most popular and powerful content management systems in the world today, WordPress offers immense customization options. So while there are a number of in-built elements, WordPress facilitates developers to also create custom elements. This customization feature extends to post types and taxonomies too.

<em>Custom post type</em> defines what type is a particular content.

<em>Taxonomy</em> is a way in WordPress to group things together. This grouping mechanism extends to posts, links or custom post types

By default, WordPress provides the below elements
<ol>
	<li>Post types = posts, pages, nav menu, attachment and revisions</li>
	<li>Taxonomies = categories, tags, link categories and post formats</li>
</ol>
<strong>How to determine the need for a custom post type or taxonomy?</strong>

I was very much happy with the in-built post types and taxonomies. However, I have learned that by bringing in custom post types or taxonomies, I can add powerful functionality to the overall application. Adding these functionalities from the in-built elements might be very time-consuming or not possible at all.

Here are some varied situations where the need for custom post type or taxonomy will be justified 
<ol>
	<li>Providing a deal site or coupons portal</li>
	<li>Importing and managing list countries with its associated meta such as ISD codes, flags etc. (<a href="https://wordpress.org/plugins/countries/">https://wordpress.org/plugins/countries/</a>)</li>
	<li>A site where chronological ordering of articles is not needed</li>
	<li>A scenario where you cannot use the categories and tags taxonomies to group particular content</li>
	<li>Use custom post types instead of databases for WordPress e-commerce plugin (<a href="https://wpecommerce.org/">https://wpecommerce.org/</a>)</li>
	<li>Adding custom meta boxes and fields</li>
	<li>Adding an image based slider (<a href="http://soliloquywp.com/">http://soliloquywp.com/</a>) to the website</li>
</ol>
<strong>The value it added to my WP project</strong>

The need for custom post arose when I needed to provide a functionality to the user to work with movies, genre, star cast or ratings as a base. Thus my code looked something like this

function post_type_mov ()

{

register_post_type( 'films',

array( 'label' =&gt; __('Movies'), 'public' =&gt; true, 'show_ui' =&gt; true ));

register_taxonomy_for_object_type('post_tag', 'films');

}

add_action('init', 'post_type_mov');

&nbsp;

This way, I can add a new movie and add all meta for this particular movie (cast, ratings, genre, similar to, comments etc.) Now, users can find information and carry out actions based on these meta fields. I can then add a taxonomy for ordering between ratings and actors. By adding in custom post and taxonomy, users can read only through the desired genres or actors, instead of going through ALL my posts within the website. This helps me in providing an enhanced UX/UI experience.

Write in to us with your comments and let us know how useful custom post type or taxonomy was in your WordPress development project. If this article helped you in your development work, do join us on social media with your valuable feedback.]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>

		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>104</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

		<category domain="category" nicename="development"><![CDATA[Development]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="wednesday-wisdom"><![CDATA[Wednesday Wisdom]]></category>

			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_yst_is_cornerstone]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[interface_sidebarlayout]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[default]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_wp_old_slug]]></wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[custom-post-type-or-taxonomy-wordpress]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Use Magento Hole-Punching to Derive Performance and Full Page Caching</title>
		<link>http://dreamhtml.com/techies-new/use-magento-hole-punching-to-derive-performance-and-full-page-caching/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 18 Mar 2015 08:11:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[webmaster]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://techiesindiainc.com/?p=2198</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">At TII, I have been utilizing the </span><span style="color: #0563c1;"><span style="text-decoration: underline;"><a href="http://www.magentocommerce.com/magento-connect/cache-full-page-cache.html"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">Page Cache</span></a></span></span><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;"> extension to give a tremendous user experience thrust to Magento applications. Full Page Caching (FPC) offers gold standard advantages such as quicker page load time, minimal server load and SEO friendliness. However, it did present a tricky situation on a recent e-commerce application development project, which had FPC turned on because of the huge number of projects to display. In order to go one step ahead, I had created blocks to store relevant product content. However, enabling this dynamic page functionality creates a contradiction with FPC functionality. This blog looks at a nifty way to overcome this issue with the help of hole-punching. So lets dive in.</span></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2199" src="http://techiesindiainc.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/Harish.png" alt="Harish" width="594" height="774" /></p>

<h3 align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">What is full page caching?</span></h3>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">Simply put, the full page caching mechanism allows local storage of web content from a URL to a container or cache. This way Magento does not need to fully initialize content and then load content to show to a user. This renders blazing fast page load speeds and lesser stress on backend databases. But it also makes the site less dynamic. However, Magento does recognize the emphasis on dynamic content and provides a built-in hole punching process to accomplish a dynamic page that provides much better and highly optimized performance.</span></p>

<h3 align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">What is hole-punching?</span></h3>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">I am assuming that you are fairly proficient in Magento and its building blocks before you read further. The thought process behind Magento EE FPC is to create a container class that is derived from </span><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;"><span style="color: #444444;"><span style="font-family: Consolas, monospace;">Enterprise_PageCache_Model_Container_Abstract</span></span></span></span><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;"> for every block having dynamic content. In order to preserve the dynamic relationship of blocks and templates with FPC, I can surround the files with a container. This denotes the working behind hole punching</span></p>

<h3 align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">The various states of Magento FPC</span></h3>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">If you are using Full Page Caching (FPC), you ought to know the four states of Magento FPC</span></p>

<ol>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">Page caching on but no dynamic blocks  In the simplest form, Magento gets a request to load a non-dynamic page. It looks up the page in the FPC repository and loads it to the user. This process puts no load on the server</span></p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">Page caching on and dynamic block caching on  Again Magento gets a request to load a page (this time, a dynamic page). Now Magento encounters a container associated with a dynamic block. If the block is cached, it will use </span><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;"><span style="color: #444444;"><span style="font-family: Consolas, monospace;">applyWithoutApp($content)</span></span></span></span><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;"> and fill up the container accordingly. This type of content loading places minimal server load.</span></p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">Page caching on and dynamic block caching off  Now imagine if Magento does not encounter a container. Now it needs to follow some steps as below</span></p>

<ol>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;"><span style="color: #444444;"><span style="font-family: Consolas, monospace;">pagecache/request/process</span></span></span></span><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;"> receives a request which then leads to its processing and routing to RequestController </span></p>
</li>
	<li><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">This accesses the method </span><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;"><span style="color: #444444;"><span style="font-family: Consolas, monospace;">applyWithApp($content)</span></span></span></span><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">. Here, the dynamic block is initiated and built using </span><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;"><span style="color: #444444;"><span style="font-family: Consolas, monospace;">.$this -&gt; renderBlock() </span></span></span></span><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">within the </span><span style="color: #333333;"><span style="font-family: Helvetica, sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: small;">Enterprise_PageCache_Model_Container_Abstract</span></span></span><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;"> container class</span></li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">This way, the container is replaced with the static block and can be used later for caching.</span></p>
</li>
</ol>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">Page Caching turned off  When the page is not cached, Magento takes the standard route of looking up the dynamic block, wrapping it around with its appropriate placeholders using the cache.xml file (present in </span><span style="font-family: 'Courier New', monospace;"><span style="font-size: small;"><span style="color: #444444;"><span style="font-family: Consolas, monospace;">Enterprise/PageCache/etc/cache.xml</span></span></span></span><span style="color: #333333;"><span style="font-family: Helvetica, sans-serif;"><span style="font-size: small;">)</span></span></span><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">. It enables FPC with the help of a cache_id and relevant block and template information.</span></p>
</li>
</ol>
<h3 align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">The outcome</span></h3>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">Imagine a visitor, Peter visits my site the first time. Now Magento will be fully initialized, FPC is newly enabled, and the desired page cache is loaded. On the second visit, only FPC hole entries and customer related cookies are loaded. On the third visit, however, the Magento remains fully initialized and hence server load is reduced drastically. For scores of site visitors, this first step is not repeated again and again for most visited pages (unless of course, Peter is visiting a non FPC page for the first time). Thus, overall server load is reduced, page load is quicker and performance is enhanced significantly. On the frontend, an increase in number of users still allows the site to work faster.</span></p>
&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>A Developers Perspective to Apple Watch App Development</title>
		<link>http://dreamhtml.com/techies-new/a-developers-perspective-to-apple-watch-app-development/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 25 Mar 2015 08:13:01 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[webmaster]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://techiesindiainc.com/?p=2201</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;
<p align="JUSTIFY">With such a huge international frenzy around Apple Watch, it is certainly early days for iOS developers like me. However with my endeavor to stay ahead of the learning curve, I have done a fair bit of tinkering with aspects related to development for Apple Watch. My thoughts are that it is not very different from standard iOS app development except for an additional layer of integrating the watch with an Apple Device (iPhone iOS8 and above). Here are my initial thoughts on the development aspect around Apple Watch.</p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2202" src="http://techiesindiainc.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/janu.jpg" alt="janu" width="594" height="774" /></p>
&nbsp;
<p align="JUSTIFY">The first thing to know is that you need two SDKs that are bundled together </p>

<ol>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY">WatchKit app (to process the Apple Watch app functionality)  Contains the layout and resource file used with the app</p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY">WatchKit Extension (that utilizes the resources of iPhone)  Contains the code to integrate iPhone responses to Apple Watchs triggers</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p align="JUSTIFY">These extend the functionalities and user interface of iPhone on to the watch. Two types of user interfaces are possible with these bundles -</p>

<ol>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Full functionality  Users can access the full range of functionalities and navigation just like a standard app</p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Read-only functionality  Much like a regular notification or alert, the read-only functionality named glance provides a glimpse of timely updates and information from the app.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<h3 align="JUSTIFY">The WatchKit app and extension</h3>
<p align="JUSTIFY">This app resides on the watchs home screen and facilitates a medium to interact with the main app stored on the iPhone and paired with the watch. It has the ability to display full data or subset of the data depending on the programming. While the WatchKit app is the face of the watch, the WatchKit extension is the brain of the watch. It contains the program to control content and multimedia, and give apt response to a particular trigger or user action.</p>

<h3 align="JUSTIFY">The Glance interface</h3>
<p align="JUSTIFY">This is an exciting Apple Watch-only user interface presented keeping in mind the small screen space. These glances fit the screen and arent navigable. They cannot be scrolled and do not have any buttons, menus or switches. Tapping a glance will bring up the WatchKit app that you can use for further action.</p>
<p align="JUSTIFY">The main thing to note from a development point of view is that instead of using separate executables, the glance functionality can be crafted inside the WatchKit app and extension development space. With help of the same classes or methods, you can create a glance as well as a WatchKit app.</p>

<h3 align="JUSTIFY">Tailor-made notification interface</h3>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Another interesting area is the ease with which custom interfaces can be built for local as well as remote notifications on Apple Watch paired with an iPhone. While initially any notification starts off as a one line brief glimpse, on user action, it can expand to display further information. You get to customize the interface to add graphics, change the details appearing in the notifications or even give it a look distinct from the full app interface of iPhone.</p>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Apple Watch offers in-built actionable notification support through iOS8. This will help us developers to create buttons depicting possible set of actions on the interface. For example, a notification for a vote can have a Vote For and Vote Against button. With automatic support on actionable notifications, you can get appropriate buttons added to your apps interface with help of the WatchKit extension.</p>
<p align="JUSTIFY">To conclude, the development landscape is in a pretty nascent stage for wearable technology. However, I am pretty sure these pointers will provide a good starting point in the world of developing for Apple Watch.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>9 Tips for Crafting Zend Framework 2 Modules Better</title>
		<link>http://dreamhtml.com/techies-new/9-tips-for-crafting-zend-framework-2-modules-better/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 01 Apr 2015 07:07:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[webmaster]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://techiesindiainc.com/?p=2205</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">During my recent pursuit of working with and creating Zend framework 2 modules, I have had the opportunity to rub shoulders with a number of great resources and to venture into territories unexplored before. Indeed, the experience has taught me a lot about the PHP language, and I now have better direction and focus when it comes to writing code that is robust, more flexible and safe.</span></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2206" src="http://techiesindiainc.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/robin-singh.png" alt="robin-singh" width="594" height="774" /></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY">In this article today, I can offer some nifty tips for those who possess a basic skill level in Zend framework 2, and want to create modules that are useful, versatile and value-adding. I have observed that many modules do not observe the simplest of rules when it comes to power of usage and functionality. Hence, these tips will help out developers who have the will to create something good, powerful and tailor-made for their clients.</p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">Here are what I feel can be some crucial tips to write high quality, high performance modules for Zend framework 2 </span></p>

<ul>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">Before you start working your groundbreaking idea into a stellar module for Zend framework 2, you need to check if an identical module has already been written by someone. If there is one already in existence, you can send pull requests and help make it better, instead of creating a new, redundant module. Run a search with your chosen keywords and ensure that you are making something entirely new and unique.</span></p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">To make your modules more flexible and conducive for tailor-made configuration, if your module has features can be configured to suit the users needs, add to them the option of configuring them.</span></p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">Try to always set your hard dependencies in the constructor. To avoid possibilities of exception errors, avoid setter/getter code and initializers.</span></p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">Zend 2 closures are not cache-able, and it is more efficient to make use of explicit class factories and define them in the module configuration file.</span></p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">To keep things as open as possible, use the service manager to create most of your objects for more transparency in dependencies.</span></p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">I have found untested modules to be a cause of major concern in the past. Create unit tests for your modules compulsorily, to ensure that they are well-written and function without problems.</span></p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">Not unlike other important frameworks of the present time, Zend 2 has a number of strict code conventions that I recommend every developer should know in detail about. Apart from the industry standard PSR-0/1/2 conventions, there are also some important conventions about where you need to store your files. For example, if your module has many different options, it is always better coding to centralize these into an Options class.</span></p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">Like many developers, I have found that using Composer to handle inter-module dependencies can have its advantages. When your module is complete and ready for use, make sure that you host it both at the Zend framework 2 modules page, and with Packagist.</span></p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><span style="font-family: Cambria, serif;">Remember that Zend is a modular framework, and many users might not like having to download the entire framework to resolve the dependencies in your module. To make it easier for users, set only those dependencies that you absolutely need.</span></p>
</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Link Earning while being Penalty-safe in 2015</title>
		<link>http://dreamhtml.com/techies-new/link-earning-while-being-penalty-safe-in-2015/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 15 Apr 2015 07:50:53 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[webmaster]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://techiesindiainc.com/?p=2220</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p align="JUSTIFY">Link earning is still one of the most effective ways of attaining supremacy with Google search rankings. Together with other beneficial activities like driving user engagement, using high quality content, and on-site optimizations, I have found that quality links make a large difference with Google. While Google considers links to be a major factor while ranking websites, their policies also show that they discourage active link-building efforts. I have seen Google dish out penalties for paid links, directory submissions and article marketing.</p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2221" src="http://techiesindiainc.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/harvinder-puri.jpg" alt="harvinder-puri" width="594" height="774" /></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY">The system of penalties has been slowly but gradually put in place to encourage the mindset of earning links, and not building them through inorganic processes. By implementing these penalties, Google has set up a system of penalizing link <i><b>building </b></i>and reward link <i><b>earning</b></i>. One problem that I have faced with this system is that for websites with no initial audience, link earning might become a difficult proposition.</p>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Let us take a closer look at some of the important points that Google make in their Webmaster Guidelines </p>

<ul>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Buying or selling links is discouraged.</p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Mutually beneficial link quid pro quo is discouraged.</p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Flooding of guest-posting campaigns with keyword-rich text links is discouraged.</p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Automated link-generation programs are discouraged.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p align="JUSTIFY">These are just some of the interesting caveats that I have found to be of importance as far as Google is concerned. For the year 2015, these are my tips to earn links without attracting Google penalties </p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"></p>

<ul>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Buying or selling links is discouraged.</p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Mutually beneficial link quid pro quo is discouraged.</p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Flooding of guest-posting campaigns with keyword-rich text links is discouraged.</p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY">Automated link-generation programs are discouraged.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p align="JUSTIFY"></p>
<p align="JUSTIFY">These are just some of the interesting caveats that I have found to be of importance as far as Google is concerned. For the year 2015, these are my tips to earn links without attracting Google penalties </p>
<p align="JUSTIFY"></p>

<ul>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><b>Using the Right Tools </b> Putting together the right tools for the job is important to start off with. I use Google Chrome as my browser of choice, along with the SEO Quake, Moz and Majestic Backlink Analyzer extensions. I have also found great value in the collaborative project management tool Podio, which I use to create, manage and distribute content.</p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><b>Developing Content </b> Link earning is all about developing compelling content that would make people want to link to your site. I try to analyze trending and engaging topics and niches using tools like Buzzsumo to find out more about creating content that addresses particular problems, answers particular questions and provides value. I also try to diversify my content with the use of multiple media, infographics and videos. This is also the right time to figure out your link naming strategy.</p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><b>Preparation of Reaching Out </b> I then reach out to sites that have similar content. I use Google to find the relevant websites, and keep track of the search keywords with a utility like Trello. This is followed by the collection of contact details and the drafting of my individual, tailor-made pitch for those places that I decide to target.</p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><b>Getting in Touch </b> I use Gmail with the Streak Chrome extension to send out my pitches. I also categorize my emails and responses into separate areas for easier retrieval.</p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><b>Responding </b> Once you start getting responses (I get both actual replies and autoresponders) it is time to start categorizing them and responding to each one individually. The idea is to start building a relationship and develop insight about each prospect, and use that insight to drive conversation.</p>
</li>
	<li>
<p align="JUSTIFY"><b>Final Steps </b> The moment you receive positive feedback, it is time to start creating and distributing your content. Make sure to include friendly reminders about publishing your content.</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p align="JUSTIFY">I have always found that earning links is hard work, but the results can be extremely rewarding in terms of Google rankings. Do write in with your comments on your perspective on link earning.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Make Your Web Development Project, Google Searchs Best Friend</title>
		<link>http://dreamhtml.com/techies-new/make-your-web-development-project-google-searchs-best-friend/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 22 Apr 2015 18:16:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[webmaster]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://techiesindiainc.com/?p=2226</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Almost all of my developer friends would vouch for the importance of on-site SEO for a happy and profitable client. Getting an SEO site up and running is a true effort involving a web designer, SEO strategist, backend and frontend coding, and information architect. Their joint collaboration is what creates a truly lasting web experience that results in satisfied end customers and a delighted client.

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2227" src="http://techiesindiainc.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/Gourav-Verma.jpg" alt="Gourav Verma" width="594" height="774" />

Lets look at some ways in which different stakeholders can add value to the development work and make Google Search their websites new best friend.

<strong>How front end coders can implement SEO friendliness </strong>
<ol>
	<li><strong>CSS over tables</strong>  This not only facilitates enhancement in the way elements are ordered in the site, but is also preferred by Google spiders.</li>
	<li><strong>Use of heading tabs</strong>  Use the h1 to h4 tag only for content that is used once on the site. For repetitive content, its better to use &lt;div&gt; tags</li>
	<li><strong>Machine-friendly fonts</strong>  This one is where I see most developers faltering. I have got equal SEO success with @font-face and using machine-readable fonts.</li>
	<li><strong>Images</strong>  Using &lt;img src&gt; within &lt;a href=#&gt; gives a good way to display the right alternative text. So if CSS is turned off, the image is still displayed. If both are turned off, the alt text is shown.</li>
	<li><strong>Website load time</strong>  Use the general rule of taking 3 secs to load a site on 10MB connection. The coders can control some part of the website load speed by combining CSS/javascript, using image sprites, loading javascript etc.</li>
	<li><strong>Dynamic content loading</strong>  Avoid loading content dynamically after site loading is done (by using AJAX or &lt;script&gt; tags). Google search crawlers do not easily pick up such dynamic loaded content.</li>
</ol>
<strong>How back end developers can implement SEO friendliness</strong>
<ol>
	<li><strong>Canonical URLs</strong>  A canonical link element is used to inform Google search bots of the preferred version of a webpage. So ideally all webpages should have only one URL. But for individual parameters added/removed from the URL, canonicalization helps developers specify the preferred version of a page. This can be done in one of the below was </li>
</ol>
<ol>
	<li><strong>Usage of www</strong>  Ideally all three below should redirect to the same page</li>
</ol>
i. myhome.com

ii. www.myhome.com/index.php

iii. myhome.com/index.php

&nbsp;
<ol>
	<li><strong>Usage of trailing slashes</strong>  Both of the below non-root URLs should redirect to the same page</li>
</ol>
i. www.myhome.com/about-us

ii. www.myhome.com/about-us/
<ul>
	<li><strong>Usage of canonical link tags</strong>  This is especially true for an e-commerce website where every product should have a single URL redirect</li>
</ul>
i. www.myhome.com/product/simmer-purple-curtains/

ii. www.myhome.com/furnishings/product/simmer-purple-curtains/

iii. www.myhome.com/furnishings/house/product/simmer-purple-curtains/

&nbsp;

By using canonical link tag on a common URL (&lt;link href=www.myhome.com/home/product/simmer-purple-curtains/ rel=canonical), you can tell Google that it needs to index this URL for both the below examples

&nbsp;

www.myhome.com/product/simmer-purple-curtains/?cat=furnishings

www.myhome.com/product/simmer-purple-curtains/?cat=furnishings&amp;subcat=house

&nbsp;
<ul>
	<li><strong>CMS best practices</strong>  Having a few quick tweaks as below helps in your SEO process</li>
</ul>
<ol>
<ol>
	<li>Updating the sitemap.xml</li>
	<li>Making the robots.txt file editable</li>
	<li>Stick to a 3 sec load time limit by following some nifty tips <a href="http://gtmetrix.com/recommendations.html">here</a></li>
	<li>Configure 404 page not found instead of 302 or 200 for a non-existent URL</li>
</ol>
</ol>
Hope these pointers give you sufficient impetus to craft amazing SEO experiences when executing web development, both at front-end and back-end.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Are you measuring the RoI on your Social Media strategy?</title>
		<link>http://dreamhtml.com/techies-new/measuring-social-media-roi/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 29 Apr 2015 11:19:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[webmaster]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://techiesindiainc.com/?p=2230</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Not knowing the answer to the below dreaded question of the client is a common concern for Social Media companies for their efforts - <em>How do I know that our social media marketing strategies are delivering the expected outcomes?</em> If you are scratching your head at this question then worry not. I will share some of my real-world experiences in how I managed to determine the RoI for social media efforts for many of our clients, to help convince them that their social media outreach campaign with Techies is actually bearing fruit. [fvplayer src="http://techiesindiainc.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/How-to-measure-Social-Media-ROI1.m4v" width="500" height="500"] <strong>First off Why is it needed?</strong> RoI on social media programs provides clear and tangible evidence that our Internet marketing efforts are showing the desired results. It encourages client to continue with continued engagement with the experts. It also becomes important to track RoI correctly in face of ever changing Google algorithm updates, and evolution to tools to measure efficacy of social media programs. Here are some steps, tips, tools and tricks to get an answer to the above question
<ol>
	<li><strong><em>Set concrete social outreach goals</em></strong>  Before setting a RoI measurement strategy, know the objective behind the same. This will help you choose from various social media RoI measures such as</li>
</ol>
<ol>
	<li>Lead generation</li>
	<li>Conversion rate</li>
	<li>Click ratio</li>
	<li>Revenue generated</li>
	<li>Contest and promotional outcomes</li>
</ol>
Once you are sure of what you are running after then devise measures to effectively monitor the situation and assess correctly when your efforts are successful.
<ol start="2">
	<li><strong><em>Which platform will you target</em></strong>  Every business has a target audience and every segment spends a majority of their time in one or the other social media platform. The obvious favorites remain Facebook, Twitter and LinkedIn.</li>
</ol>
But what if your client is a photographer and most of his target audience are on Pinterest? Any effort put on other platform will not bear the same splendid results as targeting Pinterest will. So choose your target platform based on where you can maximum from target segment.
<ol start="3">
	<li><strong><em>Monitor your social media campaigns</em></strong>  I believe that the below tools are best to show you how your campaigns are performing </li>
</ol>
<ol>
	<li>Google Analytics  Is the perennial favorite amongst free yet immensely powerful analytics tools.</li>
	<li>Simply Measured  Provides a very elaborate social media reporting platform, with competitive analysis and benchmarking</li>
	<li>Rival IQ  Is the best for gaining critical competitive intelligence. You can suggest a list of competitors and it tracks their social media performance.</li>
	<li>Zuum  Helps to find what competitors are up to, obtain engaging content and ascertain chief influencers</li>
</ol>
&nbsp;
<ol start="4">
	<li><strong><em>Reporting the numbers</em></strong>  It isnt sufficient to track numbers if you cannot report it into easy to understand and quick to comprehend format. Check out Convince &amp; Convert if you need to report on your Google Analytics numbers. If you need something more comprehensive then its worth looking at UberVu reporting template.</li>
	<li><strong><em>Review efficacy and re-calibrate</em></strong>  Now that you have the numbers with you, it can be used to check desired vs actual outcomes on all points in marketing efforts, including paid advertising. If the campaign is consistently showing negative then its time to re-calibrate expectations or bring in better approaches or systems to meet the desired level of performance.</li>
</ol>
<strong>To wrap up</strong> While initially it will look a bit overwhelming to create an RoI measurement strategy for social media, in the long run, it does serve your business needs of showcasing your talent and gaining more business from referrals or repeat business. Do write in to us and let us know your views of these tips to design the right social media RoI measurement tactics.]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Decode Dark Social using UTM Parameters</title>
		<link>http://dreamhtml.com/techies-new/decode-dark-social-using-utm-parameters/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 06 May 2015 10:45:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[webmaster]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://techiesindiainc.com/?p=2245</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[fvplayer src="http://techiesindiainc.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Decoding-Dark-Social1.m4v" width="500" height="500"]

As a Digital Marketeer, you might have come across various incidents where you might have seen increase in traffic for your website. But, don't know where it comes from, what are the sources.

In this article I will try to answer your questions related to unknown audience and help you understand where this audience found you.

Imagine this Scenario: You're at work and it's hitting 4 o'clock on the wall. To revive your spirits, you browse through Facebook and find huge discounts on the brand of denims you wanted to buy lately. You flip through their collection and find three pairs quite appealing but you are confused which one to buy. You quickly copy the URLs and send it on Skype to your colleague and ask him to choose one for you.

Congratulations, you have just entered into Dark Social act.

So,

<strong>What is Dark Social or Dark Traffic?</strong>

We have all done this. We have shared articles, blogs, news, products on chat, messaging apps, IM and in email  outside the mainstays of the digital marketing ecosystem. Then, there are sites which do not collect any information on users, do not use their cookies.
<h2><em>Techopedia says,</em></h2>
<em><strong>Dark social is a term coined by Alexis C. Madrigal, a senior editor at The Atlantic (http://www.theatlantic.com/), to refer to the social sharing of content that occurs outside of what can be measured by Web analytics programs. This mostly occurs when a link is sent via online chat or email, rather than shared over a social media platform, from which referrals can be measured.</strong></em>

<em><strong>The prevalence of sharing through dark social suggests that social media marketing that fails to focus on the type and quality of content may be overlooking a huge portion of social sharing. - http://www.techopedia.com/</strong></em>

<strong>Understanding the Percentages for Dark Social</strong>

Alexis C. Madrigal coined the word Dark Social. In 2012, Madrigal wrote an article for The Atlantic called <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2012/10/dark-social-we-have-the-whole-history-of-the-web-wrong/263523/"><em>Dark Social: We Have The Whole History of the Web Wrong</em></a>

Madrigal findings revealed that 56.5% of total traffic to The Atlantic website was Dark Social. Following is the break-up of traffic generate on The Atlantic:

<a href="http://techiesindiainc.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/pie-chart-.png"><img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-2250" src="http://techiesindiainc.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/pie-chart-.png" alt="pie chart" width="308" height="161" /></a>

Photo Credit: The Atlantic (http://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2012/10/dark-social-we-have-the-whole-history-of-the-web-wrong/263523/)

By looking at these percentages, you can very well understand how Big Dark Social can be. This explains the amount of your marketing efforts go wasted and you cannot understand which are the prime sources of traffic.
<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>I understand it has become very complicated and you might be confused.</strong></p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><strong>Here is the solution, so keep reading.</strong></p>
<strong>Decoding the Dark Social or Dark Traffic:</strong>

After understanding the Dark Social, your marketeer brain must have started looking for the possible options to break the Dark Social Labyrinth.

There is one way to un-hide your hidden audience. This can be done using UTM parameters.

Just-in-case you are not aware about UTM parameters 

<em>They are little codes added manually to the URL of a website. They are basically the tracking codes which help a marketeer understand the Where? When? What ? How? of audience. They help you monitor the audience coming from particular codes.</em>

So, next time you run marketing campaigns on different platforms don't forget to use UTM parameters. And Voila! You know where your audience is coming from.

Understanding the UTM parameters: http://www.koozai.com/blog/analytics/utm-parameters/]]></content:encoded>
